item.title: Determinants of Psycho-Social Adaptation in the Spanish Second Generation: A Fixed-Effects Analysis
Irregular Status, Territorial Confinement, and Blocked Transnationalism: Legal Constraints on Circulation and Remittances of Senegalese Migrants in France, Italy, and Spain
Legal Status, Gender, and Labor Market Participation of Senegalese Migrants in France, Italy, and Spain
How Well--Still Good? Assessing the Validity of Self-Reported English Ability
item.description: I wanted to share a recent blog post that I wrote at the Census Bureau on the validity of the self-reported English-ability question that has been in use for over 30 years. The bottom line: the results suggest that the English-ability question, despite being a self-assessment, does a good job of measuring English ability. Speakers of languages other than English with the best self-reported English ability can perform the same key tasks as the average English-only speaker.

item.title: How Well--Still Good? Assessing the Validity of the American Community Survey's English-Ability Question
Baganha Dissertation Award talk
item.description: I was recently at the IMISCOE Annual Conference in Geneva to accept the 2015 Maria Ioannis Baganha Dissertation Award. You can watch my talk on YouTube!

item.title: Emigration Nations: Policies and Ideologies of Emigrant Engagement
Winner of the 2015 Maria Ioannis Baganha Dissertation Award
item.description: I am honored to be selected as the winner of IMISCOE’s 2015 Maria Ioannis Baganha Dissertation Award. The purpose award is to “stimulate and recognise excellent PhD research in the field of migration, integration and social cohesion in Europe”. I look forward to accepting the award at the upcoming IMISCOE conference in Geneva, on Friday, June 26 2015.
